Amazing seaside view, fun atmosphere, and good service. The dishes were pricey, about $33 per person, but for lobster that is to be expected, and the naked roll was served with minimal seasoning. Delicious fish quality. Would be a go-to if it weren’t for the price.

name: Chez Dasso
review: Simple fish dish, which was nice after a day of fasting to go to Djoudj bird park. Less nice was the ~hour wait time to get the fish, despite a lack of customers, or the lack of communication about this. The dish was quite simple, decent quality fish in sauce with rice on the side. That being said, absolutely nothing spectacular.

name: La Linguere
review: Serviceable Yassa Poulet. A bit pricey for Senegal, but doable for a restaurant. That being said, the flavor is simply roast chicken with caramelized onion, nothing that will surprise you. There’s probably better on the island that I did not see.

name: Chez Mame Penda
review: This was a small home restaurant on Goree Island, an easy day trip from Dakar. While I was enjoying the beautiful scenery, I went there. It was closed, but they offered to open early to serve this. Great! A truly family restaurant, basically a house courtyard with some tables. If you don’t mind flies in open-air outdoor kitchens (which, seeing that you are in Senegal, you deeply shouldn’t), the food quality was very good. Well cooked chickens. The onion soup served, for some strange reason, was possibly the best soup I’ve had in my life. Simple, but transcendent.

name: Hunan House
review: This place had two reviews, but was one of the very few places open on the fourth. Apparently the beef was good, but I always order duck. Funnily enough, I expected the buns to be pork buns, not desert fried bread buns, and the duck to be more like Beijing duck. Both were good, but the duck got repetitive after a while: it could have used more flavoring. Decent portions for the price.

name: Mala Sichuan
review: For the price, not fantastic, although high quantities of food. Went with Tom and Myles from 382 which was fun, and service was very quick. Other than the spice, however, the pork was a bit bland: not much sweetness or acidity. Similar story with the dumplings, albeit somewhat better. Rick was right to say that there was better.

name: Hard Knox Cafe
review: Reasonably priced soul food with bar seating. Went for lunch, so I didn't get chicken and waffles. A bit expensive for the end product, but reasonably high quality. I was sitting at the bar next to a guy who ordered 3 orders of the corn muffin appetizer (which were 2 each), he must have had a better time than I did.

name: Cascal
review: Karl from my externship very generously treated me to lunch. Great and fascinating conversation. The food was blankly not worth the $55 that my half would have been. Calamari was standard, ahi tuna was fresh but a tiny quantity. The paella was a decent seafood paella and definitely the highlight. The Cuban pork (which I never saw in Cuba) was not flavorful at all (the sweet potato fries were very good though). Service was good but the restaurant was not busy for a Sunday dinner.

name: Graze @ Hilton
review: Went here for the free restroom, stayed for the food. Hotels have famously decent food in Sri Lanka, and I would call it exactly that: decent. Too expensive, around $4 for the meal, and kottu is, I hate to admit, overrated (roti shredded in rice with general fried rice accouterments), but the restaurant itself is passable if you need shelter from the chaos that is Colombo.

name: Gami gedara
review: A place serving Sri Lankan, Chinese, and Thai food with burgers, a surprisingly common combo here. For about $2 you get a huge plate of food, amazing value and good taste. A bit far from the pure center of the city, but still easily reachable on foot and probably the best low-key Sri Lankan food I had.

name: Benthota Bake House Quick Eats
review: In the same place as the bakery, they have a decent Sri Lankan restaurant. Same good prices as everywhere else, and decent quality. We met a shady guy from Martinique there who left our table because he “needed more space” and was clearly high the whole time. You may too, if you venture in.

name: Mandiya
review: A low-key, impossible to find, tourist oriented restaurant serving Sri Lankan food in Kandy. Despite having a mixed clientele, prices are very reasonable. The chicken was tremendously flavorful and rice was good in quantity. Might have liked more meat, but the side vegetables were good. Quick and easy.

name: Cafe 113
review: Poya and I randomly wandered in here for our first meal on Sri Lankan soil. It did not disappoint. Mostly empty, we had buffet style choices and picked the pork. About $5 for both of us, the sauce was spicy and portion sizes very big. Generous with meat too. Come here if you are in the area.

name: Wago Sushi
review: Sushi restaurant in a good location with very regular special rolls. Good sizes for the price. Shockingly, I liked the California roll the most, really fresh and actually decently affordable. The cherry blossom roll was just tuna and avocado with tobiko, which the tuna overpowered. Rock N’ Roll is a solid unagi with a good sauce, but I found that in Wilkes Barre as well. Not impressive, but serviceable.

name: Azuma Sushi (under new name I forgot, but this is the maps pin location)
review: Why would Kota Kinabalu have good sushi? I have no idea why I thought it might. The salmon was quite good, the chicken quite bad, and the random thing we didn’t order but couldn’t get refunded due to (my) bad handwriting was mediocre. Prices were relatively high and portions were small, small, small. Go anywhere else other than the Hungarian restaurant we avoided.

name: Sushi Ave
review: Seattle is cheap compared to the Bay! An okay, serviceable sushi restaurant that is very small without great service. Fine in a pinch, but not overtly recommended: the walk from the light rail is not particularly pleasant either.

name: Zushi Puzzle
review: A strange, but decently affordable sushi restaurant on the Marina. Went after visiting the Golden Gate Bridge with a group with three people I didn’t know before. Fun experience and solid sushi, but nothing stellar.  Omakase is expensive, but apparently most recommended. Service was mediocre, after refusing to take our bill for a while I downgraded the group tip.

name: Kaori
review: Nice and trendy restaurant in a large Hillsdale stripmall area. The unagi lover roll was delicious, with a good sauce, tempura eel, and roe. Salty and sweet, and reasonable portions as well. I only ordered this, however, because even that roll was $25 post tax. Everything is expensive here, but that does not stop me marking down absolute, rather than locally relative, prices in the Bay.

name: Akira
review: A nice vibe in a nice small city. A cryptic back entrance did not stop us from devouring the giant portion sizes here after a very long hike in Big Sur. Rice was not tremendously flavorful, but the quality of the fish was very high and there was tons of food for the price. Recommended for value.

name: Kara
review: Ceviche Sushi C- Crunchy Fish C+ Cappuccino B Too much rice on the sushi, very little fish for a $20 pricetag. The fish was not immensely high quality, and the soy sauce was of poor quality as well. Amazing sea view, and one dollar coffees were very good. An hour and a bit wait before the (admittedly large) group to get food.

name: Nippon
review: For the price, very solid traditional sushi. Probably wouldn’t go for specialty rolls, but for plain rolls the quality of the fish was good. Slow service. Nice ambiance in the middle of nowhere.

name: Yokohama
review: Probably my most commonly eaten restaurant, and by far the best fare within 30 minutes of Roxbury, CT.  Great food with slow service, and specialty rolls are great.  Sushi quality is amazing too, with consistently good salmon, eel, and tuna.  It doesn’t hurt that the clientele is also exceptionally eccentric and willing to speak.

name: Golden Phoenix

foods.name: Western Sirloin Steak w/ Garlic Sauce

review: A bizarre look into what a fever dream of a US steakhouse might be, but one that was surprisingly good for HK $130. I was told by Cederic to have low expectations for the steak, but it was quite decent. Likely filled with tenderizers and mildly drowned by sauce, but for the prices it was very satisfying. The 10 minute wait before being seated was less satisfying, and the vegetable soup was about as satisfying as that: a bog standard tomato soup. This was the most “East-meets-West” experience I’ve had here (mostly seems to be East-meets-East), a truly Hong Kong take on steak for the proletariat.

name: Porterhouse
review: Ah, luxury! To have $100 of a steakhouse expensed by the internship, lovely to talk to the team as our last hurrah before the reorg. Was the steak good? No. Relatively flavorless and extraordinarily expensive, I would absolutely not go back. Tremendously grateful to have had it for free, however. If you are a software engineer in the Bay, you could do worse with the company card, but don’t foot the $80 bill yourself.

name: The Keg
review: This restaurant was chosen after we were kicked out of a Portuguese restaurant without a reservation.  Decent, kind service.  However, the steak was quite bland for the price-point, and food was slow to come.  Excellent calamari and bread didn’t wash the sour aftertaste of that mediocre steak, although it served admirably in a pinch.

name: Carnitas Michoacan
review: A really good, local Beacon Hill restaurant. We walked by every time to get to the light rail and decided it would be fitting for a last meal: it did not disappoint. $3.5 for one taco was steep for Seattle but worth it: the salsa bar and add-ons were absolutely delectable. Great meat quality. Bustling, even on a Monday lunch.

name: Taqueria Los Primos #1
review: Decent tacos at a sitdown restaurant in suburban SM. Cash only and mostly Spanish speaking. $3.5 for tacos that were not any better than the food trucks, but still a decent place. They remade food when a minor mistake was made too, so decent service.

name: Tacos Peralta
review: Not as good as Lilo’s, but another good street taco truck. $2.50 per taco is an amazing deal, and the tacos were very flavorful. I was warned that they were spicy: they were not. Delicious flavor and meat quality.

name: Lilo’s Kitchen
review: Probably the best tacos I’ve ever had. Amazingly flavorful and with a great soft corn wrap. Each taco is small, but for $3 (sans tax) it’s hard to complain. The truck is efficient, with little seating outside, but plenty of people would come and chat around it. Good vibe, great food.

name: T-Lounge
review: A beautiful, trendy, tourist trap in Colombo. They said they had good Ceylon Tea: I buy it’s as good as you can find in Sri Lanka, but it makes sense that it is so popular in Great Britain: Ceylon tea is meant to be covered by milk. Practically undrinkably bitter black, which is how I had it. The cake was overly rich and not sweet. Has plugs and wifi, though, so I like tourist traps.

name: Kafe
review: This is a strong invocation of the rule that it is categorized under what I ate there, it’s just trying to be a trendy American place. I’m not sure how a tourist trap can survive on a road without lighting and tons of stray dogs in a remote city, but apparently it can. The food was not amazing, although the taco was better than I was expecting, not loaded on cheese but with good sauces on the side. Great Wifi, which was my primary concern.

name: Chimichanga
review: Why did I let two Europeans bully me into visiting Tex-Mex in Singapore? Small portions (2 tacos) and highly mediocre flavor for $14 US. Generous on avocado, stingy on service quality. When Singapore is about as far away from Mexico as possible, I advise sticking to food from Afro-Eurasia.

name: Chipotle
review: Internship friends dragged me here against my will for the first time. I am devastated to report that it is pretty good: the guacamole and meat quality is great. Nothing inspiring: I won’t crave it, but okay for its price range. You can easily do worse, and that is pretty sad.

name: Malakor Kitchen
review: Mediocre, touristy restaurant in Ayutthaya. Serviceable lunch, with decently flavorful rice. Great location near the historic center, but nothing memorable.

name: Saneh Mookrata
review: No relation to Saneh Restaurant. Mookrata is Thailand’s KBBQ equivalent. I prefer it, with much more flavorful sauces. I didn’t put enough lard on the metal top at the beginning and burnt the meet, but the waiters taught me how to do it and were very happy to chat to a solo traveler, even after I paid and was about to leave. Meat quality is high and there are reasonable sides too, nothing not to like.

name: Saneh Restaurant
review: Dirt cheap food that Deivid and Saba loved. I disagree. The service is inordinately impolite, which is fine. However, the food is just not that flavorful. Any of the other $ beats it for 30 more baht. I think it being under a bridge and not giving you food poisoning makes people think that it’s good and not passable.

name: Pad Thai Station
review: Next to the monolingual Thai name place near my hotel. Great pad thai for B60, flavorful. Not the cleanest place, my table had food from the earlier group, but if you care about cleanliness, food safety, or service then I don’t want to be associated with you in any way.

name: Peppery Thai Bistro
review: For the price, this was not good. The green curry was flavorful but small, especially for the meat. The coffee was good, but not as good as the place right next to it. The fact that this was my worst meal so far in Bangkok furthers my thought that it’s the best food city I’ve ever been to.

name: Khun Phu Curry Puff
review: A quick, cheap-as-hell place (30 us cents per puff) to get little curry puffs, think tiny empanadas with curry chicken inside. Very filling and delicious. A good way to stave off hunger in Bangkok, but if you’re ever hungry here you’re doing it wrong.

name: Zara Maldivian Restaurant
review: On the verge of A-. Name aside, this is a cafe with great Thai food as well. Extraordinarily flavorful, with great sauce and meat quality. Easily the best pad thai I’ve had in my life.

name: เด็ดกะเพรา สุขุมวิท22
review: For B60, ridiculously good food. Passed up nearby pad thai for this restaurant without an English name. It’s on the street, so no amazing seating, but the flavor on the pork is worth it. Spicy is not that spicy. Egg is highly recommended as an add-on.

name: New Thai Elephant
review: Chosen by Myles to meet up in the city as he was starting up his job. Very fun meeting, but the food was relatively forgettable. The chicken was quite plain, with a mediocre peanut sauce, and the moo krop was very light on pork. Instead, there was much more flavorless Chinese broccoli. Rice was not included. Serviceable, but not recommended.

name: Chai Yo [Vegetarian]
review: Went after work. Took me a few seconds of eating to realize that all dishes were vegetarian and mock meat: there was substantially more progress on this front than I thought. Good service who amended prices back to the menu when there was a price hike. Duck was especially decent, and I would go back despite the somewhat high price.

name: Thonglor
review: Solid Thai place chosen by consensus after the Giants-Orioles game. Cramped seating and no atmosphere, but everyones’ dishes looked decent. Duck a la carte was $23, $18 with rice, but was a decent portion of delicious duck with a vinegary sauce. In a slightly lower price range, it would be highly recommended.

name: Bro’s Kebab
review: A solid, fast-food, kebab shop. Not gigantic portions, but open during Ramadan and good flavor on the sauce. Bread was also decent. Nice service, but not chatty. Sat next to an absolutely obnoxious gaggle of French grandmas who made the experience worse. They went over to me and peered over my order, frothing with some entitled rage. They get a D-.

name: Kebab World
review: Really mediocre (and expensive) kebab chain in Dakar. They were obviously open, and so I went in despite my better judgment. My better judgment was, well, better. Small portion, mediocre meat. The employees were watching English football and mildly included me in the watch party, so that was fun at least.

name: Turkyano
location: Yau Ma Tei, Hong Kong, 06 October 2023 (Lunch)
review: Bog standard doner in residential Kowloon. About $100 for fries, a drink, and the doner, pretty fair for Kowloon. Soft bread and decent sauce. Fries were shockingly good, the best I’ve had in Asia (of 2). If you’re craving a doner, here’s the place, not nearly as good as Midyat though…

name: Cobani
review: Delicious wrap in a humble but comfortably decorated restaurant. Quick service. The deciding factor, however, is price: $13 for a large sandwich means that this is the cheapest decent lunch I’ve found here. Good meat quality and a nice salad on the side.

name: Istanbul Kebab House
review: Well cooked Turkish food in a city not known for that.  Server was especially kind.  Doner was not available due to mechanical failures, but the wrap, especially with cabbage, was delicious.

name: Sultan’s Turkish Restaurant
review: Really fun restaurant with extraordinarily kind staff that I talk to often. Quality can be a bit inconsistent and availability is not always amazing, but is always fun when in Western CT.

name: Mansur Shashlik
review: A very fancy restaurant without that many people (maybe due to being a 30 minute walk outside the city center). Beautiful area with great seating and a friendly waiter who was very excited to talk to Americans. Amazing shashlik, easily the best of the trip and the food I remember most fondly. Cheap, like most Uzbek food not aimed at tourists. Almost exclusively speaks Russian.

name: Tian Shan Cafe
review: A touristy restaurant in Charvak, a beautiful lake area of Uzbekistan. National food as you’d expect with English service. Plentiful portions and good flavor. The manti were a bit bland, but the plov was solid.

name: Huong Duong
review: Stopped as Othello Station was halfway between Beacon Hill and the airport. This was about as much of a convenience pick as possible. Okay prices, but the food quality was very mediocre: the spring rolls matched Trader Joes quality. The noodles were slightly better, but even the 5/5 spicy hardly put a dent in me. This is a mediocre Vietnamese place in an incredibly diverse city: look elsewhere.

name: Pho Vietnam

foods.name: Pho Combo (beef, short rib, tripe, tendon)

review: Situated in the middle of a dismal strip mall of surprisingly adventurous foods, at least by Western Connecticut standards, my family popped by here after a dental visit stopped us from eating lunch. Possibly the hunger biased me, but the pho was absolutely phenomenal. Amazing broth, good portions, and good meat quality. Dumplings were interesting, my first experience with congee. Very good coffee, slightly sweet but legitimately solid without the milk and sugar. I would question whether child labor laws were violated considering the servers, and there was a loud Youtube video playing from the kitchen, but if you, like me, don’t particularly care about a quiet ambience or youth enrichment then the establishment is your best bet for Vietnamese in Danbury.
